channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: NATO Summit Ends, Leaving Leaders to Sell Their Pledges Back Home
item.description: Western leaders departed the meeting with new commitments to a united front against Russian aggression, but they face the challenge of persuading their own people that it is worth the cost.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Everything in Hong Kong Has Changed’: A Road to Reinvention
item.description: In the 25 years since the handover to China, life on Queen’s Road, the first thoroughfare built by the British after they seized the territory, has been transformed.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Sergey Ponomarev

item.title: Biden Vows to Back Ukraine ‘as Long as It Takes’ Despite Economic Toll
item.description: NATO leaders concluded a summit with new commitments to a united front against Russian aggression, but they face the challenge of persuading their own people that it’s worth the cost.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger, Jim Tankersley, Michael D. Shear and Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden during a news conference on Thursday at the conclusion of the NATO summit in Madrid.

item.title: Patient and Confident, Putin Shifts Out of Wartime Crisis Mode
item.description: Cloistered and spouting grievances at the start of the war on Ukraine, the Russian leader now appears publicly, projecting the aura of a calm, paternalistic leader shielding his people from the dangers of the world.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin of Russia arriving in Ashgabat, the capital of Turkmenistan, on Wednesday to attend the Caspian Summit.

item.title: How Vitaliy Kim Became a Symbol of Ukraine’s Resistance
item.description: Applying the lessons of taekwondo, the regional military leader has rallied the embattled southern city of Mykolaiv.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vitaliy Kim has worked to puncture the legend of Russia’s might. “It was important to convey that the enemy was not as scary as it seemed, and to tell the world that we are here, that we exist,” he said.

item.title: Israel’s Parliament Dissolves, Paving Way for Election in November
item.description: The decision brought down the coalition government and installed Yair Lapid, a centrist, as interim prime minister. Exhausted and exasperated Israelis will be asked to vote again in November.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Yair Lapid shaking hands with Naftali Bennett, front right, the departing prime minister, after the vote to dissolve Parliament on Thursday.

item.title: Belgian Court Finds 10 Guilty Over Ties to Paris Attacks in November 2015
item.description: The convictions followed the end of a giant trial in the French capital over the same massacre, in which 130 people were killed.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Constant Méheut
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Belgian police standing guard in the Molenbeek district in Brussels, in Ma rch 2016.The neighborhood was home to key members of the terrorist network that plotted the Paris attacks of 2015.

item.title: What Is NATO and Which Countries Are Members?
item.description: This Western mutual-defense alliance, which recently said it would increase the number of troops on standby, is central to the war in Ukraine, even though Ukraine is not a member.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: Romanian soldiers at a military air base used by the NATO Response Force. The alliance has promised to bolster forces on its eastern flank.

item.title: Xi Jinping, China’s Leader, Visits Hong Kong, Cautiously
item.description: Before Xi Jinping’s tightly controlled appearance, Hong Kong sent officials, diplomats and others to hotels for days of isolation and Covid tests.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Zixu Wang and Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, arrived in Hong Kong on Thursday for celebrations marking the 25th anniversary of the city’s handover from Britain.

item.title: Marcos Becomes President in the Philippines
item.description: The son of the former dictator used his inauguration speech to discuss the economy and the need to heal a deeply divided country after a polarizing election.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez and Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: Ferdinand Marcos Jr. taking the oath of office as he was sworn in as president of the Philippines at the National Museum of Fine Arts in Manila on Thursday.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Bankrolls a Challenge to the PGA
item.description: Saudi Arabia is investing in sporting events, like an upstart golf tour, as part of a yearslong drive to turn the country into a hot spot for business and tourism and to blunt criticism of its human rights record.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Phil Mickelson putting at a tournament in Saudi Arabia in 2020. He’s now one of the stars of the Saudi-backed LIV Golf circuit.

item.title: To Save Its Honey Industry, Australia Is Killing Bees by the Millions
item.description: Australia is the only major honey-producing country that has so far managed to contain the spread of a mite fatal to bees. That distinction is now in peril.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:description: A beekeeper inspecting hives in Bowral, New South Wales, last year.

item.title: Egypt’s Iconic Nile Houseboats Face Demolition
item.description: Divas hosted debauched salons on them, and a Nobel laureate wrote a novel on one. “They’re a kind of romantic dream,” one well-known writer said. “They’re so much a part of the heritage of Cairo.”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Nada Rashwan
item.media:credit: Heba Khamis for The New York Times
item.media:description: This month, the government suddenly ordered houseboats on the Nile in Cairo, like Ekhlas Helmy’s, center, demolished, saying they were unsafe and unlicensed.

item.title: After Israel’s Spies Hit Iran Hard, an Intelligence Official Loses His Job
item.description: After a series of damaging failures, a senior Iranian intelligence official lost his job and a Revolutionary Guards general was said to have been arrested.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Hamed Malekpour/Agence France-Presse, via Tasnim News/Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: Before he was removed from his post last week, Hossein Taeb presided over a vast and feared intelligence apparatus in Iran.

item.title: 20 Men Convicted in November 2015 Paris Terrorist Attack
item.description: The verdict capped a 10-month trial on the Islamic State rampage of November 2015 that killed 130 people, traumatized the country and still shapes French politics.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Aurelien Breeden
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside the Palais de Justice in Paris this month during the trial for the November 2015 attacks.

item.title: ‘Wearing a Piece of History’: Vintage Clothing Stores Find a Growing Market
item.description: The demand for repurposed clothes is rising in Australia, store owners say, as shoppers look for sustainability and history over fast fashion.
item.dc:creator: Manan Luthra
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Newtown, a suburb of Sydney known for its quirky retail outlets and abundance of thrift stores.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: A Major U.S. Climate Ruling
item.description: Plus Xi Jinping visits Hong Kong and Ukraine takes back Snake Island.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.S. Supreme Court is seen in Washington, D.C. on Thursday.

item.title: Court Decision Leaves Biden With Few Tools to Combat Climate Change
item.description: A Supreme Court ruling, combined with an energy crunch and intraparty politics, makes it nearly impossible for President Biden to achieve his climate goals.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden met with governors, labor leaders, and private companies last week to discuss a federal and state partnership to develop more offshore wind energy.

item.title: Biden Endorses Ending Filibuster to Codify Abortion Rights
item.description: The president called the Supreme Court’s decision overturning Roe v. Wade “destabilizing’’ and said Congress needed to act to codify it into law.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Jim Tankersley
item.category: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden speaking Thursday during a news conference at the conclusion of the NATO summit in Madrid.

item.title: Missing From Biden’s Europe Trip: An Endgame for War and Cheaper Gas
item.description: The G7 and NATO meetings this week underscored the pressure on Western leaders caused by soaring energy costs resulting from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden is already feeling political heat from his swift response to the Ukraine invasion, though few of his opponents in the United States are explicitly framing it that way.

item.title: A Powerful Court
item.description: In other advanced democracies, the courts are more restrained.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court’s structure allows for few checks on the justices’ power.

item.title: An Instagram hot spot becomes a display of loyalty to the mainland.
item.description: Hundreds of crimson Chinese flags appeared on the white balconies on two 28-story buildings in a soaring residential complex.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: Chinese and Hong Kong flags hung from a residential building in Hong Kong to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the city’s handover to China.

item.title: Russian Forces Withdraw From Snake Island, a Setback for Moscow
item.description: The retreat came after sustained Ukrainian attacks, including with newly arrived Western weapons, made it impossible for Russian forces to hold the island.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko

item.title: In Athens Creativity in Art, Food and More Rises
item.description: The Greek capital has added impressive arts venues, daring restaurants and a blossoming hotel scene to its well-known Classical draws.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:credit: Maria Mavropoulou for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the heart of the city near Greece’s Parliament, the Athens Capital hotel has an extensive roof deck.

item.title: Day Care Centers Brace for Effects of Younger Children’s Covid Vaccinations
item.description: Federal action to make children older than 6 months eligible for vaccines not only affects parents but also day care centers, which have struggled throughout the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan and Christine Chung
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Johanna Villa, a preschool teacher, reading with her class at Seward Child Care Center in Minneapolis in February.

item.title: Xi visits Hong Kong amid high security and inside a Covid bubble.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Zixu Wang and Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, hailed Hong Kong, a city transformed by Beijing’s crackdown on dissent, as “reborn from the ashes.”

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: A prisoner exchange in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: More than 2,500 Ukrainian soldiers surrendered to Russian forces in mid-May after fighting in Mariupol, Ukraine, from their base in the bunkers of the Azovstal steel plant for months.

item.title: Fauci, Recovering From ‘Rebound’ of Covid, Praises Paxlovid
item.description: Dr. Anthony Fauci, President Biden’s top pandemic adviser, sought to discourage doubts about the antiviral drug Paxlovid following what appeared to be a “rebound” of Covid-19 after taking the pills.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:description: “I’m 81 years old, I was at risk for hospitalization and I didn’t even come close to being sick enough to be hospitalized,” Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, pictured earlier this month, said on Wednesday.

item.title: The U.N. has documented at least 3,924 Ukrainian civilian deaths in the war.
item.dc:creator: Maham Javaid
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A gravedigger working at a site where 30 unidentified bodies were buried last week in Bilohorodka, near Kyiv.

item.title: A More Muscular NATO Emerges as West Confronts Russia and China
item.description: It is a fundamental shift for a military alliance born in the Cold War and scrambling to respond to a newly reshaped world.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden with the NATO secretary-general, Jens Stoltenberg, left, and Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez of Spain at the NATO summit in Madrid on Wednesday.

item.title: Unilever Sells Ben & Jerry’s Business in Israel, Defusing Dispute
item.description: Ben & Jerry’s, the American ice cream maker owned by Unilever, angered many Israelis last year when it pledged to discontinue sales in the occupied West Bank.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Ben & Jerry’s announcement last year was met with protests, including in New York, above, and cries of antisemitism.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: A Stronger NATO Emerges
item.description: Also, Shanghai wrestles with the scars of Covid lockdowns and religious unrest spreads in India.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. President Joe Biden (center), NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg, (left) and Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez of Spain at the NATO Summit in Madrid on Wednesday.

item.title: Putin wants to take most of Ukraine, but a quick breakthrough is unlikely, the top U.S. intelligence official says.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Although decimated by casualties, Ukrainian forces in the Donbas have managed to slow down the progression of the Russian advance along the eastern front.

item.title: Prince Charles to Stop Accepting Large Cash Donations for Charities
item.description: Charles, the heir to the British throne, runs two charities that are under scrutiny for how they have handled donations from the wealthy, including $3.1 million from a former Qatari prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Aaron Vincent Elkaim for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prince Charles received a cash donation from a former prime minister of Qatar that was delivered in a suitcase and in bags from the English grocer Fortnum & Mason, The Sunday Times reported.

item.title: Americans Who Died at Bahamas Resort Were Poisoned by Carbon Monoxide
item.description: The authorities said they did not suspect foul play when the tourists were found unresponsive in two villas at a Sandals resort on Great Exuma Island in May.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat and Johnny Diaz
item.category: Sandals Resort (Great Exuma Island, Bahamas, Hotel)
item.media:description: The deaths of three Americans stumped investigators when they were summoned to the Sandals resort on Great Exuma Island in the Bahamas on May 6.

item.title: E.U. Proposes Ban on Flavored Heated Tobacco Products
item.description: The move, which awaits review by European lawmakers and the European Council, is part of a broader campaign to phase out tobacco use almost entirely by 2040.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Euan Ward
item.media:description: A man exhaling smoke from an e-cigarette in Nice, France, in February.

item.title: Pelosi Received Communion at Vatican After Meeting With Pope
item.description: The sacrament has become a political issue, with conservative American bishops like House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s own priest, who has said he will deny her the sacrament until she stops publicly supporting abortion rights.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Pope Francis greeting Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi and her husband, Paul Pelosi, before celebrating a Mass on Wednesday at the Vatican.

item.title: Hershel Williams, a Hero in the Battle for Iwo Jima, Dies at 98
item.description: He was the last of the 27 Marines and Navy servicemen who received Medals of Honor in the 36-day fight for the Japanese island.
item.dc:creator: Richard Goldstein
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Mark Webb/The Herald-Dispatch, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Hershel Williams speaking at the Veterans Memorial Fieldhouse in Huntington, W.Va., in 2012. At his death he was the oldest living recipient of the Medal of Honor.

item.title: Ukraine Announces Prisoner Exchange, Including Mariupol Fighters
item.description: Officials said 144 Ukrainian soldiers, many of them seriously injured, were released in an exchange for the same number of Russian and proxy forces.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz, Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: More than 2,500 Ukrainian soldiers surrendered to Russian forces in mid-May after fighting in Mariupol, Ukraine, from their base in the bunkers of the Azovstal steel plant for months.

item.title: At Least 1 Dead After Heavy Rain in Austria
item.description: About 5.5 inches of rain fell over seven hours, a meteorologist said, swamping villages in the southern part of the country.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Flooding damage in Treffen, a town in southern Austria, on Wednesday.

item.title: A Canine Companion So Nice It (Maybe) Evolved Twice
item.description: Two different ancient wolf populations contributed DNA to modern dogs, according to a new study.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:description: The researchers found that ancient wolves that lived in far-flung locations were highly genetically similar, even more closely related than wolf populations are today.

item.title: Religious Unrest Spreads in India With Killing of Hindu Man
item.description: Two Muslim men filmed themselves attacking a Hindu, a tailor, who had been accused of backing anti-Islamic remarks.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:description: A crowd gathered on Tuesday in Udaipur, India, outside the shop of the tailor who was killed.

item.title: Why Finland and Sweden Are Racing to NATO Membership and Ukraine Isn’t
item.description: The imperative to seek NATO membership is written into Ukraine’s Constitution. But even President Volodymyr Zelensky has said that it may never happen.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky and Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Swedish Army soldiers listening to instructions during training in Gotland Island, Sweden, in May.

item.title: U.S. Moves Closer to Selling F-16 Fighter Jets to Turkey
item.description: A day after Turkey dropped its opposition to Sweden and Finland joining NATO, a Biden administration official said that Washington “supports Turkey’s modernization of its fighter fleet.”
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: F-16 fighter jets participating in NATO’s annual Swift Response exercise in North Macedonia in May.

item.title: Cities Across Ukraine Suffer a Steady Stream of Civilian Casualties
item.description: Despite a Russian claims to focus on military infrastructure, civilian sites have increasingly been destroyed.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Mourners at a memorial for those killed when a Russian airstrike hit a shopping mall in the central Ukrainian city of Kremenchuk on Monday.

item.title: ‘Let the people in’
item.description: Trump and his top aides knew that the Jan. 6 rally was likely to turn violent.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:description: Cassidy Hutchinson, former top aide to Mark Meadows is seen during the hearing on Capitol Hill, Tuesday, June, 28, 2022.

item.title: Philippines Orders Rappler to Shut Down
item.description: Maria Ressa, the co-founder of the independent news organization, said she would appeal the decision, calling it “harassment and intimidation.”
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: Rappler offices in Pasig City, suburban Manila, on Wednesday.

item.title: Shanghai Wrestles With Mental Health Impact of Lockdown
item.description: The lockdown fueled anxiety, fear and depression among the city’s residents. Experts have warned that the mental health impact of the confinement will be long-lasting.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: A temporary isolation center in Shanghai in April.

item.title: From Seattle, Go to Bellingham for Active Days and Appetizing Nights
item.description: The Pacific Northwest’s lesser-known jewel, Bellingham, Wash., offers world-class scenery, sculpture and seafood within easy reach of Seattle.
item.dc:creator: Julie Weed
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bellingham is popular with outdoor enthusiasts. Whatcom Falls Park, above, offers easy hiking on its four-mile trail network. passing the park’s W.P.A.-era stone bridge and splashing waterfall.

item.title: Looking for a Getaway Near Los Angeles? Try Ojai.
item.description: This small, verdant city, nestled in the mountains of California’s Ventura County, has a famous attraction that’s not to be missed. But plenty of other things about Ojai will leave you wanting more.
item.dc:creator: Sheila Yasmin Marikar
item.media:credit: Michelle Groskopf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ojai’s famous attraction, the pink moment, seen from the Ojai Valley Inn in California’s Ventura County. The phenomenon is the fleeting seconds when the setting sun illuminates the Ojai Valley in an otherworldly glow.

item.title: North of Atlanta, a Trove of Wineries
item.description: Georgia actually has a long history with vineyards. About 90 miles from Atlanta, in the shadow of the Blue Ridge Mountains, there are more than 40 wineries and tasting rooms.
item.dc:creator: Tariro Mzezewa
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kaya Vineyard and Winery in Dahlonega, Ga., above, has panoramic views of the Blue Ridge Mountains in a region of the state with more than 40 wineries and tasting rooms.

item.title: The Best Books to Take You Through Lisbon, Portugal
item.description: The award-winning Portuguese novelist Djaimilia Pereira de Almeida recommends books to help readers get to know Portugal’s vibrant capital, and spots to read them if you go.
item.dc:creator: Djaimilia Pereira de Almeida

item.title: NATO Formally Invites Finland and Sweden to Join the Alliance
item.description: The historic deal underscores how the war in Ukraine has backfired for President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, center, after the agreement clearing the way for Finland and Sweden to pursue NATO membership was announced in Madrid on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Turkey agrees to NATO’s expansion.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: President Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, third from left, shaking hands with Jens Stoltenberg, NATO’s secretary general.

item.title: After Rapes by Russian Soldiers, a Painful Quest for Justice
item.description: Women who were attacked in a village near Kyiv yearn for justice. “I want them to be punished,” said one victim. But Ukrainian officials face daunting challenges in prosecuting such crimes.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Viktoriya and another neighbor were raped by Russian soldiers, who also killed two men, including her neighbor’s husband, and destroyed several homes.

item.title: Zelensky urges the U.N. to label Russia a terrorist state over a missile strike on a shopping mall.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Ukrainian servicemen standing guard near the remains of a shopping center in Kremenchuk, Ukraine, on Tuesday, a day after it was hit by a Russian missile.

item.title: Deborah James, British Cancer Campaigner and Podcaster, Dies at 40
item.description: She had chronicled her struggle with an incurable bowel tumor with candor and vivacity after the illness was diagnosed more than five years ago.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Deborah James at the Best Heroes Awards in London, England, in 2019.

item.title: As Monkeypox Spreads, U.S. Plans a Vaccination Campaign
item.description: States will be given vaccine doses from the federal stockpile, but supplies of the safest type are limited.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Hiram Durán for The New York Times
item.media:description: Men waited to register for monkeypox vaccinations outside the Chelsea Sexual Health Clinic in Manhattan last week.

item.title: In Blow to Putin, Turkey Won’t Bar Sweden and Finland From NATO
item.description: The change was a victory for President Biden and a setback to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, who had justified the Ukraine invasion as a warning against NATO’s expansion.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger, Valerie Hopkins, Anton Troianovski and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, center, after the agreement was announced in Madrid on Tuesday.

item.title: Bomb threats paralyze the Lithuanian government. The police suspect that Russia is behind them.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Andrej Vasilenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: Freight traffic across the border between Lithuania and Kaliningrad, a province of Russia, has been a subject of a dispute between the two countries.
